column5:
She might have had some past sexual trauma and not want to cite that as the reason? 

I‚Äôm a few months out of a relationship that was sexually abusive and when I dip my toe back in the dating pool I am going to be taking it VERY slowly before sleeping with anybody. 

It won‚Äôt mean I‚Äôm not attracted to the person, but being super careful with my physical boundaries is particularly important to me now... And even if it‚Äôs not because of anything traumatic, and she just prefers to take it slow because she is conservative: a month is really not that long. 

If you like her enough and sense she is attracted to you, then just wait.

It‚Äôs your boyfriend with the issue, not you or your family. Your family sound like they have been welcoming to him. He sounds kinda awful?!! Like insecure and completely oblivious to the cultural aspect of this - which is a bit of a red flag IMO. 

Next time he complains or makes a comment I suggest telling him that your family are not going to change or go away, and that many of his issues are with things linked to Indian culture (like the jewellery at weddings and whatnot) - so his constant criticism is not only rude and insensitive but simply not going to fly if he is interested in being with you long term. 

Alternatively - find a nicer boyfriend!
Are you initiating foreplay and spending time messing around before getting to sex?

Agreed. Not sure what part of the world you‚Äôre in but I‚Äôm in Aus and people seem to be acting like it‚Äôs all over now - no social distancing happening at all when I went to the supermarket the other day... it‚Äôs unnerving

Totally. I went to the store today and it seems everyone here thinks life is back to normal! So busy, and zero social distancing happening - really stressful and makes me think a second wave will hit hard üò´
I‚Äôm the same! I‚Äôm reluctant to join in on group FaceTime‚Äôs etc. - I‚Äôd still rather have the time for myself despite the fact I‚Äôve not seen anyone in 2 months üò≥ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

It flat out sounds like he doesn‚Äôt respect you sadly. How does he treat you generally?? My friend was with a guy for 8 years who was the same. It really broke her confidence because he never valued her thoughts, opinions or intelligence.

It‚Äôs pretty messed up that he‚Äôs more concerned with the ‚Äúdeal‚Äù and his desires than what you‚Äôre comfortable with. It sounds like he is more concerned with some giant boob fetish of his being realised than your comfort - it doesn‚Äôt matter if there was a ‚Äúdeal‚Äù, you‚Äôre not 10 years old agreeing to trade particular Pok√©mon cards - it‚Äôs your body and your feelings, and two extra kids is not something you base a trade on. 
He sounds like a bit of a dick tbh. I‚Äôd go with the size YOU are comfortable with.

I disagree with the people saying if she‚Äôs not sleeping with you she‚Äôs doing it with someone else, and the comment saying she is probably asexual - desire is completely nuanced and fluctuates for different people and at different times in peoples lives. This doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre asexual or hiding the fact they‚Äôre actually really sexual but seeking it elsewhere.

Have things always been this way with her (i.e. since you got together)? Sexual trauma can have a strong affect on someone‚Äôs desire to have sex - are you aware if she has had any bad sexual experiences prior to you?
Do you use Duolingo? I‚Äôm finding it helpful because the exercises are super repetitive (in a good way) which helps with retention..?

I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs too late - I know someone who did a business degree, graduated, started working at a top organisation and then decided at around 24-25 to switch into medicine. When I met him he was in his early 30s, in his first year or two as a junior doctor, and was completely dedicated to the field.

Fear for me is this heightened sense of being under threat (even if objectively, I‚Äôm not) - and it is mental/emotional, but primarily physical (my body goes into flight or fight mode, heart racing, cold sensation, clammy etc.). In many instances for me it‚Äôs the feeling of really NOT wanting something to happen, that you think could happen, and then your body jumps ahead and responds as though it WILL happen.

Lack of fear has been linked to psychopathy, though there has been research that has cast doubt on that theory and suggested that psychopathy actually involves a limited ability to see danger..... there is also a disease called Urbach‚ÄìWiethe (hereditary) that apparently affects the part of the brain responsible for fear and can result in people feeling zero fear.
Thanks for this :) I just DM‚Äôd you answering your question (albeit in a very long-winded manner, haha).
Keen to know what your career change was too! üôè

Definitely go for what you‚Äôre passionate about - but instead of focusing solely on forensic science perhaps instead write down the qualities of that type of role that appeal to you, and your current soft skills that you think would align you with that kind of work. You might end up with a list of things that other areas/jobs would also satisfy. 

At the end of the day, if you choose something you want to do, work hard, and take every step necessary to get there I really don‚Äôt see how it wouldn‚Äôt work out for you in the long run. Just make sure you‚Äôre realistic about what forensic science entails day in and day out, and check that you‚Äôre not glorifying it. Easy to do with ‚Äúdream jobs‚Äù.

Can you give some examples of what he has said to make you think he is sexist/racist? If your values are misaligned it will be excruciating to try and make it work in the long run. Also - isn‚Äôt him being racist and sexist just super off putting in itself??

Definitely feel for you in this situation (and anyone else whose livelihood/financial stability has been impacted). Money stress is awful and I‚Äôm well aware I am in a privileged position to still have a full time permanent job. I wouldn‚Äôt be feeling content if that was gone and I had no way to pay my mortgage. I hope things work out for you.

If I didn‚Äôt have a full time job that kept me occupied for 8 hours weekdays I would probably be feeling differently. So I understand without that element of structure, this could be really disorienting. I guess people have different triggers for their anxiety too - some crave stability, others flexibility, some people genuinely need minimal social contact and others need more. People would have differing levels of discontent with their pre-covid lives too, which I suspect would shape how they feel about the restrictions/changes. This would be hell for some and a welcome escape for others. What‚Äôs the saying? One man‚Äôs trash is another man‚Äôs treasure... I think that‚Äôs applicable to this situation too. 

Most people I know are really struggling with iso for many of the reasons you listed. I‚Äôm not happy the economy is going to sh*t, or that people are sick. But this has given me space in my life that I really craved - I have more time to read and exercise and draw... and I genuinely don‚Äôt need much social contact at all. In fact I‚Äôm happy I don‚Äôt have to see people I once felt obligated to connect with. I get this isn‚Äôt how everyone feels though - and I do think the majority of people feel similarly to you!

You‚Äôre definitely not alone - I posted on here because I am literally the only person in my social and professional circle who is happy in isolation - I was starting to feel like I must be a total weirdo because everyone I know has been wanting to go back to normal :)
It‚Äôs been really nice to know I am not the only one feeling this way - seems a lot of us are in the same boat thinking these things ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

God I would feel exactly the same. I am dreading when that moment comes for me so I feel for you! 
It feels like we should be eased back into it right?! Like a slow transition, instead of throwing us straight back on the hamster wheel

That‚Äôs incredible (the drop in your migraines), but also disturbing because it is such a clear indication that the ‚Äústandard‚Äù working situation has a serious impact on your health (and probably for many of us in more subtle ways!). I get migraines occasionally and they are truly awful, I cannot imagine getting 30 a month. üòû

Totally get this!! And while I wouldn‚Äôt wish the feeling on others it‚Äôs so nice to know I‚Äôm not alone. This time away from the normal grind has allowed me to reflect and I‚Äôve realised how much I deeply dislike my work culture / hierarchy too (and many of the big personalities that dominate it). I feel sick at the thought of going back to that. Not to mention having to put makeup and regular clothes on every day again üòÇ

It sounds really toxic, and will definitely start to chip away at your confidence if you stay with her. It‚Äôs so hard to go through with a break up but I strongly think you should consider ending things.... people like that don‚Äôt change, either.

Narcissist or not, if she is making passive aggressive comments and criticising what you wear etc. she‚Äôs not right for you. No one needs that. A relationship should build you up not tear you down in small subtle ways.

You should go no contact with your ex. If it was meant to be you wouldn‚Äôt have broken up. Or he would be beating down your door wanting to be back together. Maintaining a friendship so soon after a breakup is not healthy in my opinion.
Don‚Äôt hinge too much on NGwP but continue getting to know him.

I do similar!! Except deep down I actually believe I‚Äôm inferior to everyone and expect rejection, so rejecting them first through aloofness/keeping them at arm‚Äôs length is my self protection mechanism. However this is only in group situations - 1:1 I‚Äôm fine, I guess because it‚Äôs ‚Äúsafer‚Äù. Keen to see what books people suggest for you

Unfortunately I don‚Äôt have an answer for you but I wanted to comment to say I know how you feel!! My recent ex did the same, and made me sound like a nagging fishwife because no matter how clearly or frequently I asked him to stop swearing, he didn‚Äôt. It was so off-putting and made me feel disrespected when he continually ignored me. Hopefully someone has some good advice on how you can get him to stop...

I think anything preceded by ‚ÄúI should‚Äù often triggers an inner rebellious teen in our subconscious that doesn‚Äôt like being told it ‚Äúshould‚Äù do anything (even if it‚Äôs good for us). ‚ÄúShould‚Äù can trigger guilt and shame, and these aren‚Äôt positive motivators.

Try to just connect with ‚Äúwhat would feel good for me right now?‚Äù. If you sit with that question sometimes the answer is to watch trash on YouTube, and that‚Äôs okay! Other times you might sit with it and realise, actually, it would feel good to go for a walk or have a snack or read a book (or whatever). 

It might not be a buzzy motivation technique that will have you running a marathon in a month, but if you can work on it, it‚Äôs a sustainable, long-term perspective shift that will continually and quietly motivate you to do what feels best for you. Like a slow burning log on the fire rather than a sugar hit of motivation :)
Thank you so much. Really appreciate this.
No I haven‚Äôt.. do you have any recommendations on where I can find good ones?
NTA. This is great. Go you üèÖ

Going against the crowd here as I‚Äôm going to say NTA.   All relationships are different and for some women, their partner commenting on other women is okay. 

It has never been ok with me so I feel you - but luckily I‚Äôve also never had a boyfriend that did it anyway. It‚Äôs just an unspoken rule for a lot of relationships - we KNOW our partners are going to find other people attractive, but it doesn‚Äôt need to be shared/expressed if you‚Äôre not comfortable with it. 

He‚Äôs not considering your feelings. If the pornstar pic was a meme as you said, then I still don‚Äôt think he needed to say he‚Äôs horny. He could have said ‚Äúhaha‚Äù and left it at that. The kid is insensitive.

Edited to add: don‚Äôt let a fear of being the ‚Äúcrazy girlfriend‚Äù stop you from setting healthy boundaries around what feels good/bad for you in a relationship. If you figure out how to set and maintain your boundaries in relationships now, your future self will thank you and it will help build your self esteem. Not wanting your partner to openly express his attraction to other women in front of you is not a crazy girlfriend request.

There‚Äôs a spectrum of quality right up to high end art printing which is archive quality. 

For decent quality (but not top end), I used to print on 300gsm paper (card-like stock), on a bright white linen blend paper. 

This was adequate for my needs and suited my work but it depends on your art style too. If your work is super intricate or delicate then a thinner, textured stock might be more suitable...

Highly recommend finding a printer in your area who you can talk to and who can show you physical samples of their different paper options so you can see and feel them yourself :)

Edited to add: it has been awhile since I did prints but off the top of my head I think I had the file at 400-800 DPI ! Also matte finish is generally better so there‚Äôs no reflection (IMO anyway).

NTA. You had a girlfriend / date already which is a perfectly acceptable reason to turn down another person (disabled or not). It wouldn‚Äôt have been right if you ditched your girlfriend to go with this girl either. I feel bad for your classmate but it‚Äôs not your responsibility to cast aside your partner to make her feel good (as harsh as that may sound..).
100%. I wouldn‚Äôt sleep properly if I couldn‚Äôt lock it even though my home is super safe!

I broke up with my boyfriend of a few years several weeks ago and I had the exact same thoughts and fears. I even posted here asking if it was normal to have dumper‚Äôs regret. Now that more time has passed I do not regret the decision - for me it was just initial panic that has since faded. If you don‚Äôt see yourself marrying this guy and you eventually want to get married to someone - ending things was the right thing to do. If you didn‚Äôt LOVE this guy‚Äôs company and weren‚Äôt itching to see him then ending things was the right thing to do. 
Give it a couple more weeks and see how you feel..

Not able to answer your question as I‚Äôm not one of ‚Äúthose people‚Äù but I have a couple of theories and am curious to hear a workaholic‚Äôs answer too. 

I suspect it might come down to investment/interest in a job - or maybe that‚Äôs just me. I have a really good and well paying corporate job but i have no desire to throw in loads of extra hours either. As soon as it hits 5pm I am ready to go and unless under exceptional circumstances, I generally resent it if I get held there over time. 

On the other hand when I worked in a super creative role a few years back I would get so into my projects I would lose track of time and I didn‚Äôt clock how long I was working. I miss that feeling. So much more satisfying personally - but financially not so much. It just didn‚Äôt pay very well and I wanted to buy my own home. 

I have colleagues in the corporate scene who don‚Äôt have a passion outside of their role and their job IS that passion for them - which I guess is why they can happily put the hours in. Others seem to have a massive achievement complex where their self worth is tied to their sense of achievement at their job - which is what drives them to overwork.

I think your capacity for self-reflection is admirable and a quality you should be really proud of. A lot of people wouldn‚Äôt even question their urges and would just succumb to them with hedonistic enthusiasm. 

But to reflect on what kind of person you want to be and to try hard to align your actions with that is awesome - and not easy. So good for you üôå

Don‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôre not alone. I am in a similar boat. I find it weirdly stressful because it‚Äôs like I‚Äôm missing out on life. But I‚Äôm trapped on the hamster wheel for now as I can‚Äôt afford to get off...
Amazing. You deserve to feel really proud!!

I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs definitely something worth clocking/keeping an eye on. Even if she suspects (or even expects!) you‚Äôre going to pay for a date, it‚Äôs still polite to offer instead of presuming - so IMO this kind of tells you she lacks manners...alternatively it can be awkward to make a show of offering when it‚Äôs obvious the guy intends to pay and if this is the case for her she should at least be thanking you and offering to pay next time or for your next drinks or whatever. Does she thank you?

See your doctor - they might be able to give you non-addictive sleeping tablets to help get you off to sleep and break the pattern. If you‚Äôre against trying sleeping pills I‚Äôd suggest trying meditation apps or listening to ASMR before bed if that‚Äôs up your alley (not for everyone), and definitely making sure you are getting some solid cardio exercise in every day to war your body out..
Can you set a goal to move out so you get reprieve from your mum? Might be something worth working toward?

Thanks for this, it‚Äôs good to get varied perspectives on things. However I think after sleeping on it another night I‚Äôm settling into my decision more, as the issues I had were not the kind of things I think he could change or remedy - i.e. being able to have an in depth conversation (don‚Äôt think he could change that), and after having him cross my physical boundaries many times I actually don‚Äôt think I could return from that and feel safe and respected physically around him for a long time, even if he did a 180...if that makes sense. 

But definitely I agree that people shouldn‚Äôt toss a relationship out carelessly -  if there are a lot of good things tying people together and there‚Äôs no abuse of any form going on then things shouldn‚Äôt just be ended when each other‚Äôs imperfections crop up.

I think sometimes cutting contact isn‚Äôt a sign that the other person meant so little but that it would cause more pain and confusion if contact was maintained. I was hoping my bf and I could have ended things kindly and with closure / mutual respect after 2 years together but he literally just stormed away after I told him and said ‚Äúhave a nice life‚Äù. 

He‚Äôs very proud so he won‚Äôt reach out to me again (probably a good thing at the moment while I‚Äôve been shaky in the decision), but things ending so abruptly without a hug goodbye or even a ‚Äútake care‚Äù hurts. But when there‚Äôs 2 people with their own individual thoughts and feelings situations just don‚Äôt go the way we individually hope. 

I‚Äôm sure you meant something. From my experience and what I‚Äôve gathered from hearing my friends go through breakups, women don‚Äôt make these decisions easily and she was probably tormented by her choice like I have been. Maintaining contact may have been like stringing you along in her eyes so she hasn‚Äôt done that.. who knows.
I ended things Wednesday night and that‚Äôs been it. No contact since.

Thank you. It‚Äôs been really soothing/relieving to read this and the other similar responses. Just eases my panic and reassures me that I have made a tough decision but not the wrong one. Thank you üôè

Thank you. This is really good and helpful advice. Most of these replies are making me feel a lot more grounded in the decision I made, and I was in a pretty big spin over it so that‚Äôs saying something. Really appreciate you responding x
Thank you. I think I‚Äôm so used to him minimising things that bothered me that I‚Äôve internalised it and labeled core needs as frivolous. Really comforting to get that kind of confirmation.
I love this analogy üòÇüòÇ Thank you
Thanks for this. Really comforting and reassuring to read, particularly at the moment when my breakup brain has tossed clarity aside and is throwing all the feels and doubts at me. Appreciate it x
Sometimes the shorter relationships ending hurt more because you‚Äôre missing the possibility of what might have been if you‚Äôd given it a proper shot.

Don‚Äôt judge her for things she did as a young teenager. It‚Äôs like judging someone for another person‚Äôs mistakes because people change so much as they mature.

If she told you she was skinning cats at 15 I‚Äôd be worried, but these just sound like messy mistakes made by a young, reckless, thoughtless teen.

Not *exactly* targeting the area(s) you mentioned but a lot of big businesses and manufacturers (upstream and downstream) including mining companies are beginning to look at how they can offset their carbon emissions and are hiring people into roles to find innovative solutions to either reduce their current climate impact, offset their carbon footprint or build their social value. 

There is a pretty fertile market at the moment for people with skills that can be applied to that kinda thing. And the social side of it is super interesting too - ensuring nothing is being sourced from areas with modern slavery in place, ensuring the places in which they‚Äôre operating and interacting are not being environmentally or socially impacted in a negative way etc etc. 

Not entirely sure what you‚Äôd need to study to go in that direction but it‚Äôs a good area to move into as the ‚Äútrend‚Äù will cascade and stop being a trend (when mid tier businesses start to look to do the same thing too).

He‚Äôs definitely using his class attendees as some tool to provide him with sexual tension/build up. And it‚Äôs creepy. Imagine if you were 14 and found out your fitness instructor was watching porn before training you and then jerking off after...!
This is not normal behaviour and you should probably take it as a big red flag and run for the hills.
I‚Äôd be surprised if this is the first weird sexual thing you‚Äôve encountered with him?
Also - the waking-up-to-watch-porn-in-the-middle-of-the-night thing? Not healthy, not normal.

Try to get over him. I know it‚Äôs hard because you‚Äôve invested a lot of time into him and your natural instinct is probably to try and change his mind or wait and hope you make up. 

But you‚Äôre so young - don‚Äôt start the pattern of waiting around for a boy to call the shots on your relationship, because trust me - if you carry that through into your twenties it‚Äôs going to suck. If he doesn‚Äôt want to be with you and doesn‚Äôt have the decency to tell you (and just ghosts you instead) then move on from him with grace. Hold your head up high,  throw yourself into your friendships, school and hobbies - and move on from the guy.
Why did you break up?

As Sylvia Plath wrote in The Bell Jar (when the protagonist found herself with a coveted magazine internship - then was jarred by the fact she felt depressed even when living out her dream): ‚ÄúI was supposed to be having the time of my life.‚Äù
I felt the exact same way when moving to Europe in my early 20s - I was meant to be loving every minute of it, yet I was so depressed I could barely get myself to leave the room I was renting. I then felt even worse because I was so guilty and angry at myself for not squeezing the juice out of the experience. It became a vicious cycle. I then spent too much money (my vice  was clothes) to try and lift my mood but this put financial pressure on that made me even more depressed.

If I could give advice to my younger self - and you by proxy - I would say: stop trying so hard to love the experience there and just focus on the little menial things you‚Äôre enjoying day to day. The taste of a pastry. A joke with friends. The tiny things you‚Äôd normally not notice. Take the pressure off yourself and stop expecting to be joyfully experiencing your lifelong dream - and take bite sized chunks of it to enjoy instead. Paris is an amazing city, try to relish the little details - and if you‚Äôre depressed and can‚Äôt relish them, then NOTICE them, which sometimes ends up feeling like the same thing.

Also - are you exercising? If you‚Äôre depression prone and not taking medication getting a run or workout in every day, even just for 15 minutes, can sometimes help ease the fog.

Perhaps you could try 5mg. This is half the typical therapeutic dose and some doctors will tell you it‚Äôs ineffective at that amount - but I found it still had a big impact on my depression and anxiety management while still feeling like ‚Äúmyself‚Äù.

Don‚Äôt go for what is easier to study. I would go with the engineering degree as that is more broad and can take you a lot of places and has more opportunities that can move you towards a niche area of your interest like the car design.

You can always then teach yourself animation on the side as a hobby which is possible - maybe not to the level of a total professional but you can become pretty decent through self learning.

Good, because honestly your partner could be up there with the most talented musicians in the world and still not gain fame. There are thousands upon thousands of people trying to put their music out there - even the ones with huge followings on platforms like soundcloud don‚Äôt all end up with mainstream fame where they‚Äôre under scrutiny etc. So I think you can rest at ease until Capitol records hits him up with a contract :) (and even if that were to happen he still might not get famous as a lot of artists get signed and don‚Äôt gain fame).

Has anything happened to suggest your fianc√© will gain fame from selling his music? Or has he already begun to? 

If not I wouldn‚Äôt worry yet as even the most talented of people in the music scene don‚Äôt necessarily end up with fame to the extent you‚Äôre referring to.

Hey this is a really delayed reply but in terms of advice for how to get through cutting contact without a support network.... take this as an opportunity to learn how to depend on yourself. It is not healthy for you or any future relationship you build, be it with her or anyone else, for you to depend on external sources heavily out of fear of being alone or to pull through difficult times.

No man is an island - that is true - but to be able to weather a storm when you are by yourself is an extremely good quality to cultivate, because sometimes we all have times in our life when we are caught in a hard time alone and need to pull ourselves through. It will build your confidence too because you will realise no matter what happens with a relationship you will be ok, because you can rely on yourself to pull through. It takes the pressure off the other person, too. 

As for your social issues - I have felt the same in the past, I am naturally extremely shy and have had social anxiety to some degree or another since I was a teen...But know this kind of thing is not stationary, or set in stone. You can work to become more engaged socially and to find situations less awkward over time. But it‚Äôs exactly that - work. The only way to do it is to put yourself in awkward situations to begin with - exposure therapy. Again this will build your resilience and confidence over time even if you have awkward, cringey experiences. I‚Äôve been there.

You don‚Äôt even have to do this for now though as it might be too overwhelming to begin with. You can start with getting comfortable being on your own and not reaching out to this girl instinctively. Read, go to the gym, put extra energy into work, spend your time constructively to crowd out any idle time you might end up dwelling on her.

This girl is using you but you‚Äôre blind to it because you love her. It doesn‚Äôt mean she is a bad person or intentionally wanting to hurt you but it does mean you should take a big step back and start building your confidence and resilience away from your relationship with her.

This happened to me once. You just have to go back to your life and keep living it until eventually the ghosting becomes a bad dating story you feel detached from. It takes time but you do get over it - though you‚Äôll perhaps always have a small niggling feeling that pops up when you think of the person and you wonder ‚Äúwhy??‚Äù. You just have to carry the unanswered questions and keep going. 

I think some people are just afraid of - or really uncomfortable with - conflict, and are afraid of hurting the other person/having to directly see or deal with that hurt, and so disappearing feels like an easier way out than responsibly facing up to that, and an easier way out than dealing with the discomfort being upfront would bring *them*. Doesn‚Äôt make it right of course.

You should probably cut contact with her entirely (including muting her social media accounts etc.) for awhile. It kind of sounds like she‚Äôs doing the monkey bar thing - not fully letting go of one relationship until another is established.. which isn‚Äôt fair on you. 

Her ending things and then maintaining such a close relationship with you is also not fair and confusing/blurring the lines. You will not be able to move on if you stay in touch with her for the time being. Cut ties for awhile so you can try to move forward before you‚Äôre working with her again.

Thanks for this. I guess because of all his other good qualities I found it really hard to reconcile them with this side of him that literally doesn‚Äôt care about my physical boundaries - but it‚Äôs good to be reminded that his good side doesn‚Äôt outweigh that. Tbh I think it‚Äôs going to be a long time before I can stomach sex with anybody because it went on for so long.

This is a red flag. He prioritised clubbing with the boys over ensuring his girlfriend got home safe. Not a good sign for a long term partner.. it seems extreme to say break up because of this but if he has ditched you in this scenario I‚Äôm thinking there‚Äôs probably other incidents where he hasn‚Äôt prioritised you? If he was hellbent on clubbing he could have ordered you an uber off his phone or waited with you until the bus came at the very least.

‚ÄúYou can lead a horse to water but you can‚Äôt make it drink‚Äù... how frustrating for you. Honestly if you can‚Äôt bear the thought of living with him, don‚Äôt want children with him, and he‚Äôs not making a concerted effort to address his eating disorder, it might be worth cutting ties. Not taking care of his health is selfish because it‚Äôs affecting you too.

It sounds like he has ‚Äòavoidant/restrictive food intake disorder‚Äô (ARFID) - google it. Some kid went blind from the lack of nutrition living off a diet similar to your partners - see [here](https://www.google.com.au/amp/s/www.bbc.com/news/amp/health-49551337). 
He needs to seek professional help..

Thank you! I‚Äôm probably pushing my luck here but you wouldn‚Äôt happen to know where I could find a number or some kind of tracking platform for Italian customs (if one even exists which it probably doesn‚Äôt)? I want to try and speak to someone to see if the parcel can be located, if not to get to the buyer but to come back to me!

The guy is 33, and this is not his first rodeo. He would probably have known going into this relationship with you that there was a chance it would be a bit full on. While I‚Äôm sure he will be upset, don‚Äôt worry too much about how he will take it. Just be honest. Your twenties are precious, especially those years straight out of college where you‚Äôre working your path out, you may resent him later if you stay in this situation.
Thanks for sharing - I wish I had looked into this more before posting there. So frustrating!

There is nothing wrong with being an introvert and it‚Äôs
not something you need to get over. It just seems that way as the world more openly celebrates extroverts. 

If it‚Äôs shyness you experience (often goes hand in hand with being an introvert) that is something you can get better at pushing past. I am an introvert and naturally very shy but I‚Äôve learnt how to ‚Äúfake‚Äù being less so to the point where I actually DO feel less shy now. 

It isn‚Äôt easy though - you have to keep pushing yourself through ‚Äúexposure therapy‚Äù, doing things that make you nervous or uncomfortable (I used to be too shy to call for a pizza...! Then I got a job as a receptionist while I was studying and having to answer calls and greet people all the time helped me move past the fear). In the meantime be kind to yourself and don‚Äôt feel like you have to rush to be any different than you are. If the world was full of extroverts it would be a nightmare! We need a balance of all different personality types :)

IMO it is COMPLETELY understandable and normal that you would wonder seeing as you‚Äôve been together since you were teenagers and have only been with each other. But honestly, to have an amazing sex life after 8 years and two kids together is like a relationship unicorn - something many people in long term relationships (even happy ones!) don‚Äôt have, or don‚Äôt have consistently, and it makes me think you have a great thing going and can rest assured you are not really missing out on much, bar the experience of other people which can be overrated. Sex with a new person is often awkward and dissatisfying (not always, but often), and while the thrill of the unfamiliar can seem appealing it wears off.

You asked at the end what to do if her BF came back over so I thought it was an issue. Regardless she was in the wrong for shaming you for being who you are and you‚Äôre within your right to be upset about it. Maybe when things have calmed down and she‚Äôs not on a mood you can try telling her ‚Äúwhen you said XYZ it made me feel extremely hurt , please can you not shame me for my personality‚Äù... or write a letter. However she doesn‚Äôt sound as though she‚Äôs sensitive to your feelings so may not be receptive.. how old is she?? She sounds like a teenager.

If her bf doesn‚Äôt come back or ends things it‚Äôs because he‚Äôs not into her. That‚Äôs not on you. Even if you did act strangely (and doesn‚Äôt even sound like you really did),  people don‚Äôt just end things with a new bf/gf because of one family member acting unusually. Her making a big deal about it would give anybody a bit of a complex and make them feel stranger than they even are. Just remain polite to the guy if he keeps coming around, and you do you.

I know it sounds that way. I‚Äôm normally great at talking things out with people and being upfront but over the course of our relationship I almost completely gave up on trying to discuss any issues with him, as I would get nothing but super defensive responses from him (‚Äúwell YOU do THIS‚Äù kind of thing - or flat out denial. It was painfully frustrating).

So perhaps that‚Äôs part of why I‚Äôm reluctant to bring it up. I also suspect he will get nasty and say things to hurt me - he knows my weak spots and I am admittedly scared of what barbs he will throw at me. 

So yeah, I am flat out am terrified of a) hurting him and b) the reaction that will yield. I get it though, I just need to do it.

You won‚Äôt feel like this forever. It took me two years to fully get over my last big breakup - I would have liked it to be a faster process but we can‚Äôt rush these things unfortunately. I highly recommend staying busy and finding something to put your energy into though (its helps) - whether that be exercising, working a couple jobs to reach a savings goal, starting a new hobby or a combo of all of that. Having a sense of purpose eases the pain to a degree.

YTA though I get why you would want to read it. Diaries and the privacy of them should be respected IMO, even for a teen - but this secrecy makes them more desirable to read unfortunately. As someone who was a 13 year old diary-keeping girl once upon a time, it would be horrifyingly embarrassing to have my mum read my private expressions. Resist the urge, respect her privacy, and monitor her some other way.

NTA. Attraction is super personal and you‚Äôre allowed to find certain people / qualities / bodies attractive or unattractive. I‚Äôve tried to make myself be attracted to someone I wasn‚Äôt attracted to and it completely warped my feelings toward sex etc. because of it (in a really negative way). These things shouldn‚Äôt be forced out of a sense of obligation to be nice.

Totally get this. I‚Äôd say mine is mostly under control now but I still half avoid any trips that will require a long drive as I‚Äôm paranoid about car crashes - and if I do go on a road trip I have to drive myself (can‚Äôt let a friend drive as I can‚Äôt handle not having that control :/). However previously it was so bad that I was in tears at the airport before leaving for a three week European holiday to see friends overseas, because I was so certain something bad was going to happen.

A tactic I have found to help (which helps with any form of anxiety I think) is to keep a notebook and record every time you get anxious over travel (e.g. whenever you think you‚Äôre going to die or have an accident etc.). Over time you‚Äôll have enough entries built up that you will be able to see the pattern, how things have ended up ok after every anxiety hit, and the silliness of some of the thoughts, which helps put it into perspective..

Yup. Took me ages to bite the bullet and buy a home. I was terrified at the thought I would be tied to one spot. But then I realised that my habit of idealising everything was keeping me from being happy - and that even though prior to buying my place I could run  away anywhere I wanted at any time - doing that was unlikely to yield some far flung sense of happiness. 
I‚Äôve learnt being anchored by a responsibility can actually be a very grounding thing. And I LOVE having my own home (without housemates) to hermit in...Though I still get swept up in a wave of panic when I watch a French film and realise I can‚Äôt just move to Paris on a whim üôÑ

This sounds really similar to what I went through at 24 (I‚Äôm 30 now). I moved states to be with someone who I thought was my forever person. My entire idea of and plans for my future orbited around the presumption we would be together. When it ended it was like my entire sense of the world and my life crumbled and the rug had been pulled out from under me. I was ashamed to move back home too. By admitting to everyone we were over made it more real than I wanted to accept at the time. But I didn‚Äôt know where else to go or what to do, so I did end up back home. 

Not only was I mourning him and what we had, but the entire future I thought I was going to have with him. I actually think that was harder than losing the relationship itself - I felt completely unanchored and had to build a new reality from scratch again. It was so fucking hard. I too suffer from anxiety / depression and things like this don‚Äôt exactly help. 

It took me two years to fully recover. But during those two years even though I had terrible lows, I still managed to have fun, travel, make friends, and rebuild my sense of self without him tied to it. Now it‚Äôs all just a memory. So I get it. I really do. But you will heal. It will take time and you will continue to feel pain for some time - but I promise you will make it to the other side.

Biggest advice (besides ensuring you keep routines) is to delve into something you love doing or have always wanted to do, if you can. I taught myself a craft while healing from the heartbreak (as a way to channel the pain) and it ended up becoming a side business that I have earned decent side $$ from and met so many amazing people through. It became the silver lining to what I thought was a life-ruining event x

Hey I‚Äôm so sorry you‚Äôre in such a tough place tight now. Heartbreak, especially when you‚Äôre in an already fragile position, is absolutely crushing. I have been there and honestly I don‚Äôt think there is anything you can do to stop this pain at the moment. You have to live your way through it. And it‚Äôs horrible. But you WILL make it out to the other side so hold onto that knowledge. Definitely try to keep up a good routine and keep going to work (keep to a schedule). I say that because I find that having too much time on my hands and being idle during a time like that, when prone to anxiety and depression, is not a good combo. A routine anchors you when your emotions are chaotic. 

Hang in there and know the pain WILL fade and ease. It will also make you a stronger, more resilient and empathetic person. Sending strength x

Edited to add: I was across country when my ‚Äúbig breakup‚Äù happened too, with no friends or family. I moved back. Having that support base is important - is moving back home an option??

I‚Äôve spent a birthday by myself before, purely because it landed on a work day when everyone was busy and I was freelancing so I had the day open. I took myself out to breakfast, went to see a foreign film at a little art house cinema, and bought myself a nice pastry from a fancy patisserie. Then I caught up with my family that night after spending the day alone. It was actually really nice! I had time to properly reflect on the lovely messages / birthday wishes that were coming through and spent quality time alone doing nice things for and with myself. Enjoy!! **Edited to add: 22 is an amazing age üòä

It sounds like maybe you need to find a new therapist because the right one will not be hit and miss. It can be a difficult process to find the right fit though, and exhausting retelling your trauma to different people, so I understand if that‚Äôs not an option. It took me a long time to find the right person. 

Is moving away an option, for a fresh start away from your family? The fact he is still connected to the family would be terribly triggering - blaming his drinking is so dismissive of his complete violation - it‚Äôs no wonder you feel anxious :( 

And I completely understand that when you feel bad it‚Äôs nearly impossible to grasp that the future can feel any different (even if you cognitively understand that, emotionally it‚Äôs hard to). 

Sending you strength to move through this time of your life and to find your way to a place where you can heal.

Have you been to therapy or counselling at all after what happened to you? It sounds like you are trying to cope with the event on your own - a good psychologist or counsellor may be able to provide you with a sense of safety and support that you‚Äôre not getting elsewhere  and tools to work through this hard time. You also didn‚Äôt mention much about how your family reacted to the event - did your sister leave her husband?? If not and he‚Äôs still involved with your family I expect that would be a huge stressor. 

I‚Äôm so sorry you feel like this and that you went through what you did. If it‚Äôs of any comfort - you are very young, and this time in your life and the horrible thing that happened to you does not have to define your future.
I third that. Move out!

I know it doesn‚Äôt feel like it at the moment but you won‚Äôt feel like this forever. Nothing ever remains the same, good or bad. I‚Äôm sorry you feel this way and are feeling so much pain. But please cling to the knowledge (or, if you can‚Äôt believe it yet, then the hope) that things will not feel this way for ever. Life turns on a dime and you don‚Äôt know when everything might turn around for you. I am 30 now and my life has changed so much, and been up and down so many times since I was 22. If I had ended it all back at that age when feeling bad I would have missed out on so much. The same goes for you. Stay strong and hang in there.

YTA. This is completely out of line. If her work is not affected and she‚Äôs a nice person then there is no reason to fire her. 

She might have social anxiety, be shy, or just take a long time to warm up to people. She might also - god forbid - prefer to keep work and her social life separate. 

You should not be forcing staff to be friends - the outcome/ quality of work and a harmonious team should be the main goal.
